str2: The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Name, character, fame, reputation. From a presumed derivative of the base of ginosko; a 'name'.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A star. Probably from the base of stronnumi; a star, literally or figuratively.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle or Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: (a) I say, speak; I mean, mention, tell, (b) I call, name, especially in the pass., (c) I tell, command.
Wormwood. Of uncertain derivation; wormwood (figuratively) calamity).
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Third. Ordinal from treis; third; neuter a third part, or a third time, thirdly.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Water. And genitive case, hudatos, etc. From the base of huetos; water literally or figuratively.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Middle - 3rd Person Singular
str2: A prolongation and middle voice form of a primary verb; to cause to be, i.e. to become, used with great latitude.
Wormwood. Of uncertain derivation; wormwood (figuratively) calamity).
And, even, also, namely.
Much, many; often.
A man, one of the human race. From aner and ops; man-faced, i.e. A human being.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To be dying, be about to die, wither, decay. From apo and thnesko; to die off.
From out, out from among, from, suggesting from the interior outwards. A primary preposition denoting origin, from, out.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To make bitter, embitter; pass: I grow angry or harsh. From pikros; to embitter.
Water. And genitive case, hudatos, etc. From the base of huetos; water literally or figuratively.
